race.name: Kalona Horseshoe
race.tagline: Kalona Horseshoe. 50 miles of gravel through Kalona.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Iowa countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Iowa event. Rolling terrain with moderate access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Kalona Horseshoe is a local event in Iowa—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Iowa countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Iowa gravel race. Worth it for Iowa/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Iowa—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Iowa races: Gravel Worlds, RAGBRAI.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Kalona has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Kalona has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Iowa rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Starting at Kalona Historical Village provides clear location and parking, with packet pickup the night before and morning of race. But no details on nearest airports, lodging options, or travel logistics for a small Iowa town. The basics are covered, but you're on your own for everything else.

length.explanation: The 50km and 100km distances attracted elite competition - Michael Lambert won the 100km race while Ren Stinson podiumed in the 50K. Neither distance pushes epic boundaries, but they're proven race distances that draw serious riders to southeastern Iowa. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: The Amish and Mennonite population keeps "these roads beautiful and rustic without the complexity of asphalt." Course features "moderate terrain with rolling short steep hills or moderate, sustained climbs" - consistent climbing without technical bike handling challenges. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Race promotion emphasizes that "Iowa is not FLAT!!" with "Iowa City's rolling hills gravel" delivering 2000 feet over 50 miles. The constant "rolling short steep hills" create consistent climbing without major defining ascents. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 73°F and lows of 53°F, with a 48% chance of rain on any given day. May in Iowa delivers the "windy and rolly" conditions that define this course. The emphasis on wind as a consistent feature rather than bonus challenge reflects the reality of spring racing on exposed Iowa farm roads. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: This is Iowa flatlands starting around 700-800 feet elevation. Zero altitude considerations for performance or acclimatization. You'll get more elevation change driving to the race than racing it. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The race offers a unique opportunity to "race your bike past a horse-drawn buggy" through Amish country. The course provides "a bit of a preview of the terrain in Southeastern Iowa" with "captivating and quiet" scenery, but 50 miles on farm roads has adventure limits.

prestige.explanation: This is a brand new grassroots race that joined the Iowa Gravel Series in 2024. Your winner Chad Showalter clocked 3:53:47 - respectable but not pulling UCI pros to Kalona. It's pie and horse buggies, not podium prestige.

race_quality.explanation: The Iowa Gravel Series knows how to put on a decent event with chip timing, marked courses, and aid stations with actual food. But with only 67 finishers showing in results and zero details on course features or technical sections, this feels more like a weekend club ride with numbers. The 'windy and rolly' description tells you everything - it's fine, not fantastic.

experience.explanation: Racing past horse-drawn buggies through Amish country delivers a unique backdrop you won't find elsewhere. The post-race pie is 'mandatory' according to promotion, and the scenery gets called 'captivating and quiet.' But 50 miles of Iowa gravel roads, however scenic, doesn't exactly create lasting memories or war stories.

community.explanation: "Come for the race, stay for the amazing bakeries!" captures the local flavor that draws teams like Goosetown Racing with multiple podium finishes. Starting at Kalona Historical Village adds authenticity, though the community remains grassroots intimate rather than energizing.

field_depth.explanation: Results show at least 67 finishers with times stretching past 5 hours - this isn't attracting competitive depth. Jacob Nelson and Curtis Burton finishing within seconds of the winner suggests limited fast company. It's a small Iowa town grassroots event, not a destination race for serious competitors. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: $40-50 entry gets you chip timing, marked course, aid stations, photography, and post-race pie - that's solid grassroots value. The full season package at $399 for seven races, jersey, and meals works out to $57 per race including gear. No frills, but honest pricing for what you get.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Kalona sits in rural Iowa with no obvious nearby airports or hotel clusters. You're driving from Iowa City or Des Moines and finding basic accommodations. Cheap entry fees offset typical small-town travel logistics without big-city convenience. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

key_takeaways: Race history: New to Iowa Gravel Series in 2024 (first year noted); founded recently, part of grassroots series

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: 2024 Kalona Horseshoe Gravel Race | Iowa is not FLAT!!
videos.description:
Ride along with as we take you through Kalona and Iowa City's rolling hills gravel on the ride that is Kalona Horseshoe gravel put on by our friends over at Iowagravelseries.
Link to my buddy Kevin's Channel;
https://youtube.com/@KevDoes?si=oxuDjsijSsZvmirj

https://iowagravelseries.com/kalona/

If you would like to buy me a coffee, here's my link


https://www.buymeacoffee.com/iowagravelgang?6qwptyyrboztqw6akt364ensim=j77qy222gbf5cmayq2ybib5z5q


Thank you all for your continued support!

videos.curation_reason: First-person ride-along with over 1K views that specifically highlights Iowa's challenging terrain and gravel conditions.

videos.title: Michael Lambert - Iowa Gravel Series
videos.description:
Michael Lambert took first place in the 100km gravel race at the inaugural Kalona Horseshoe. He is sponsored cyclist with Velovit Elite, a team that just became a USA Cycling Domestic Elite Team. He's also a great person to interview. 

In this episode of the podium podcast we dip into Michael's genesis story into cycling and his relationship with the Rouge Roubaix in St. Francisville, Louisiana. Then, we take some twists and turns into training, the human condition of challenging ourselves, and end questioning the utility of USA Cycling regulations. It's a good chat, so click play and enjoy getting to know Michael a little better.

Michael: https://www.instagram.com/michaelvaughnlambert/
Velovit Elite: https://www.instagram.com/velovit_elite/

Rouge Roubaix: https://www.rougeroubaix.com/

videos.curation_reason: Interview with the 100km winner providing insider perspective on the inaugural Kalona Horseshoe race.

videos.title: Michael Lambert teaser
videos.description: First episode of 2024 we have Michael Lambert who took 1st place in the 100km Kalona Horseshoe. Episode goes live at noon, but here's a little something to tease you... it's a good story, you'll want to hear how this one ends. 😎
videos.transcript:
little risky I mean you're you're gonna
if you're going to have to go strong off
the the front you know you're you're
going to burn some matches there early
in the beginning and that's what
everyone is thinking as I go off the
front solo right yeah this guy's crazy
this is a Fool's errand why would we
follow this guy uh I'm heading towards
the first feed Zone and I'm thinking I'm
texting my director right I need a shift
cable meet me at the feed Zone he's
found a mechanic he's found a cable the
guy's ready to change this thing out
things are going
smoothly uh but I'm looking behind me
and like no one's there and it hasn't
snapped this cable but it's not working
corre right uh I get to the feed Zone
I've got like a two and a half minute
Gap and so I'm like screw it we're gonna
run it and I didn't stop I had him put
the cable and some some small Allen Keys
into a musette bag so if it snaps right
I can stop I can like adjust the limit
screws I can get
home uh but I'm not going to let this
Gap go to waste

quotes.text: We are here look at this at the uh the start of the Colona Horseshoe gravel. We came the night before so that we can get our packets picked up now we don't know how to deal with that in the morning tomorrow.
Michael took first place in the 100K there's a fantastic photo on our Instagram of him finishing the race with a wonderful bunny hop across the Finish Line he has taken flight.

terrain_notes.text: Course includes big chunky gravel sections that historically have been raced on road bikes with 25mm tires.

gear_mentions.text: Racers have used road bikes with 25 millimeter tires on the gravel sections.

race_day_tips.text: Going off the front solo early in the race is risky and will burn matches early, but can create significant gaps if executed properly.

additional_quotes.text: we came the night before so that we can get our pockets picked up now we don't know how to uh deal with that in the morning tomorrow
I need a shift cable meet me at the feed Zone he's found a mechanic he's found a cable the guy's ready to change this thing out

rider_intel.search_text: The Kalona Horseshoe is described as a mixed surface race featuring big chunky gravel sections that have historically been tackled by riders using road bikes with 25mm tires. The race includes feed zones for mechanical support and nutrition. Riders discuss pacing strategies, with early solo breakaways being considered risky but potentially rewarding if gaps can be established. The event attracts riders from across the Midwest, with some traveling from Wisconsin and other neighboring states. Race morning logistics include packet pickup the night before. The course appears to have some climbing despite initial expectations of flat terrain. Weather conditions have been described as beautiful with great turnout from the cycling community.

photos.alt: First-person view of cyclist hands on handlebars riding gravel road through rural Iowa countryside with trees and farmland - Kalona Horseshoe - Kalona, Iowa
Indoor interview shot of bearded cyclist wearing glasses and dark shirt sitting in bright room with window behind - Kalona Horseshoe - Kalona, Iowa
Close-up selfie of bearded cyclist in orange helmet and pink Rapha jersey riding through Iowa gravel roads with rolling farmland backdrop - Kalona Horseshoe - Kalona, Iowa
Course preview from Kalona Horseshoe race footage
